title: Getting Started with the panelhetero Package
text: Suppose balanced panel data \(\{ y_{} \}\) \(= 1, \dots, N\) \(t = 1, \dots, T\). : \(y_{}\): scalar random variable unit \(\) period \(t\). \(N\): number cross-sectional units. \(T\): length time series. Assume individual time series \(\{ y_{} \}\) \(t = 1, \dots, T\) strictly stationary across time heterogeneous across units. examine degree heterogeneity, focus estimating cumulative distribution function (CDF), density function, moments (.e., means, variances, correlations) heterogeneous mean, \(k\)-th autocovariance, \(k\)-th autocorrelation: \(\mu_i = E(y_{}|)\), \(\gamma_{k,} = E[(y_{} - \mu_i)(y_{,t-k} - \mu_i)|]\), \(\rho_{k,} = \gamma_{k,}/\gamma_{0,}\), \(E(\cdot | )\) denotes population mean individual time series. words, \(\mu_i\), \(\gamma_{k,}\), \(\rho_{k,}\) population mean, \(k\)-th autocovariance, \(k\)-th autocorrelation, respectively, individual time series. Note \(\gamma_{0, }\) corresponds variance. variables treated random variables ..d. across units. corresponding estimators : \(\hat \mu_i = \frac{1}{T} \sum_{t=1}^T y_{}\). \(\hat \gamma_{k,} = \frac{1}{T-k} \sum_{t=k+1}^T (y_{} - \hat \mu_i)(y_{,t-k} - \hat \mu_i)\). \(\hat \rho_{k,} = \hat \gamma_{k,} / \hat \gamma_{0,}\). Denoting \(\xi_i = \mu_i\), \(\gamma_{k,}\), \(\rho_{k,}\), parameters interest : CDF \(F_{\xi}(\cdot) = \Pr(\xi_i \le \cdot)\). density \(f_{\xi}(\cdot)\). mean \(E(\xi_i)\). variance \(var(\xi_i)\). correlations, \(cor(\mu_i, \gamma_{k,})\). Okui Yanagi (2019) propose empirical distribution estimation CDF moments true \(\mu_i\), \(\gamma_{k,}\), \(\rho_{k,}\) based estimated \(\hat \mu_i\), \(\hat \gamma_{k,}\), \(\hat \rho_{k,}\). Okui Yanagi (2020) propose nonparametric kernel smoothing estimation density true \(\mu_i\), \(\gamma_{k,}\), \(\rho_{k,}\) based estimated \(\hat \mu_i\), \(\hat \gamma_{k,}\), \(\hat \rho_{k,}\). Since estimators asymptotic biases, papers propose half-panel jaccknife (HPJ) bias correction third-order jackknife (TOJ) bias correction. addition, papers also consider cross-sectional boostrap procedures performing statistical inference. HPJ bias correction requires \(T \ge 4\). TOJ bias correction requires \(T \ge 6\).

title: Getting Started with the panelhetero Package
text: panelhetero package provides following functions: nemoment(): naive estimation moments heterogeneous mean, heterogeneous autocovariance, heterogeneous autocorrelation without bias correction hpjmoment(): HPJ bias-corrected estimation moments heterogeneous mean, heterogeneous autocovariance, heterogeneous autocorrelation tojmoment(): TOJ bias-corrected estimation moments heterogeneous mean, heterogeneous autocovariance, heterogeneous autocorrelation neecdf(): naive empirical CDF estimation without bias correction hpjecdf(): HPJ bias-corrected empirical CDF estimation tojecdf(): TOJ bias-corrected empirical CDF estimation nekd(): naive kernel density estimation without bias correction hpjkd(): HPJ bias-corrected kernel density estimation tojkd(): TOJ bias-corrected kernel density estimation discuss arguments returned values function.

title: Getting Started with the panelhetero Package
text: nemoment() function enables implement naive estimation moments heterogeneous quantities without bias correction. parameters interest means, variances, correlations: \(E(\mu_i)\) \(E(\gamma_{k,})\) \(E(\rho_{k,})\) \(var(\mu_i)\) \(var(\gamma_{k,})\) \(var(\rho_{k,})\) \(cor(\mu_i, \gamma_{k,})\) \(cor(\mu_i, \rho_{k,})\) \(cor(\gamma_{k,}, \rho_{k,})\) usage nemoment(data, acov_order = 0, acor_order = 1, R = 1000) : data: \(N \times T\) matrix panel data. row corresponds individual time series. acov_order: non-negative integer \(k\) order autocovariance. Default 0. acor_order: positive integer \(k\) order autocorrelation. Default 1. R: positive integer number bootstrap repetitions. Default 1000. function returns list contains following elements: estimate: vector parameter estimates se: vector standard errors computed cross-sectional bootstrap ci: matrix 95% confidence intervals computed cross-sectional bootstrap quantity: matrix estimated heterogeneous quantities acov_order: order autocovariance acor_order: order autocorrelation N: number cross-sectional units S: length time series R: number bootstrap repetitions Note: bootstrap results depend random number generation. highly recommended use set.seed() nemoment(). comment also applies functions.

title: Getting Started with the panelhetero Package
text: hpjmoment() function enables implement HPJ bias-corrected estimation moments heterogeneous quantities parameters interest nemoment(). usage hpjmoment(data, acov_order = 0, acor_order = 1, R = 1000) arguments nemoment(). function returns list contains elements nemoment().

title: Getting Started with the panelhetero Package
text: tpjmoment() function enables implement TOJ bias-corrected estimation moments heterogeneous quantities parameters interest nemoment(). usage tojmoment(data, acov_order = 0, acor_order = 1, R = 1000) arguments nemoment(). function returns list contains elements nemoment().

title: Getting Started with the panelhetero Package
text: neecdf() function enables implement naive empirical CDF estimation without bias correction. parameters interest CDF \(\mu_i\), \(\gamma_{k,}\), \(\rho_{k,}\). usage neecdf(data, acov_order = 0, acor_order = 1, R = 1000, ci = TRUE) : data: \(N \times T\) matrix panel data. row corresponds individual time series. acov_order: non-negative integer \(k\) order autocovariance. Default 0. acor_order: positive integer \(k\) order autocorrelation. Default 1. R: positive integer number bootstrap repetitions. Default 1000. ci: logical whether compute 95% confidence interval CDF. Default TRUE. function returns list contains following elements: mean: plot estimated distribution heterogeneous mean made ggplot2::stat_function() acov: plot estimated distribution heterogeneous autocovariance made ggplot2::stat_function() acor: plot estimated distribution heterogeneous autocorrelation made ggplot2::stat_function() mean_func(): function returns value estimated distribution heterogeneous mean acov_func(): function returns value estimated distribution heterogeneous autocovariance acor_func(): function returns value estimated distribution heterogeneous autocorrelation mean_ci_func(): function returns 95% confidence interval estimated distribution heterogeneous mean acov_ci_func(): function returns 95% confidence interval estimated distribution heterogeneous autocovariance acor_ci_func(): function returns 95% confidence interval estimated distribution heterogeneous autocorrelation quantity: matrix estimated means, autocovariances, autocorrelations acov_order: order autocovariance acor_order: order autocorrelation N: number cross-sectional units S: length time series R: number bootstrap repetitions Note: plot, x-axis limits set minimum maximum estimated quantity.

title: Getting Started with the panelhetero Package
text: hpjecdf() function enables implement HPJ bias-corrected empirical CDF estimation. parameters interest neecdf(). usage hpjecdf(data, acov_order = 0, acor_order = 1, R = 1000, ci = TRUE) arguments neecdf(). function returns list contains elements neecdf(). Note 1: Due bias correction, HPJ bias-corrected empirical distribution estimator may non-monotonic function. address issue, HPJ bias-corrected estimator converted monotonic function using Rearrangement package. Note 2: mean_func(), acov_func(), acor_func() functions returned hpjecdf() subject rearrangement. desired, can manually use Rearrangement package get rearrangement estimate. Note 3: Due bias correction, HPJ TOJ bias-corrected empirical distribution estimate may less 0 greater 1. adjust estimate 0 1.

title: Getting Started with the panelhetero Package
text: hpjecdf() function enables implement HPJ bias-corrected empirical CDF estimation. parameters interest neecdf(). usage hpjecdf(data, acov_order = 0, acor_order = 1, R = 1000, ci = TRUE) arguments neecdf(). function returns list contains elements neecdf(). Note: comments hpjecdf() also apply tojecdf().

title: Getting Started with the panelhetero Package
text: nekd() function enables implement naive kernel density estimation without bias correction using Gaussian kernel. parameters interest density function \(\mu_i\), \(\gamma_{k,}\), \(\rho_{k,}\). usage nekd(data, acov_order = 0, acor_order = 1, mean_bw = NULL, acov_bw = NULL, acor_bw = NULL) : data: \(N \times T\) matrix panel data. row corresponds individual time series. acov_order: non-negative integer \(k\) order autocovariance. Default 0. acor_order: positive integer \(k\) order autocorrelation. Default 1. mean_bw: bandwidth used estimating density function heterogeneous mean. Default NULL, plug-bandwidth obtained KernSmooth::dpik(). acov_bw: bandwidth used estimating density function heterogeneous autocovariance. Default NULL, plug-bandwidth obtained KernSmooth::dpik(). acor_bw: bandwidth used estimating density function heterogeneous autocorrelation. Default NULL, plug-bandwidth obtained KernSmooth::dpik(). function returns list contains following elements: mean: plot estimated density heterogeneous mean made ggplot2::stat_function() acov: plot estimated density heterogeneous autocovariance made ggplot2::stat_function() acor: plot estimated density heterogeneous autocorrelation made ggplot2::stat_function() mean_func(): function returns value estimated density heterogeneous mean acov_func(): function returns value estimated density heterogeneous autocovariance acor_func(): function returns value estimated density heterogeneous autocorrelation bandwidth: vector bandwidths quantity: matrix estimated means, autocovariances, autocorrelations acov_order: order autocovariance acor_order: order autocorrelation N: number cross-sectional units S: length time series Note: plot, x-axis limits set minimum maximum estimated quantity.

title: Getting Started with the panelhetero Package
text: hpjkd() function enables implement HPJ bias-corrected kernel density estimation. parameters interest nekd(). usage hpjkd(data, acov_order = 0, acor_order = 1, mean_bw = NULL, acov_bw = NULL, acor_bw = NULL) arguments nekd(). function returns list contains elements nekd(). Note: Due bias correction, HPJ bias-corrected density estimate may less 0. estimate adjusted less 0.

title: Getting Started with the panelhetero Package
text: tojkd() function enables implement TOJ bias-corrected kernel density estimation. parameters interest nekd(). usage tojkd(data, acov_order = 0, acor_order = 1, mean_bw = NULL, acov_bw = NULL, acor_bw = NULL) arguments nekd(). function returns list contains elements nekd(). Note: comment hpjkd() also applies tojkd().

title: Getting Started with the panelhetero Package
text: following simple example illustrates use panelhetero package. begin , install following packages: , using simulation() function, generate artificial data AR(1) model random coefficients follows. nemoment(), hpjmoment(), tojmoment() functions enable estimate moments heterogeneous quantities. example, can implement HPJ bias-corrected estimation follows. neecdf(), hpjecdf(), tojecdf() functions enable implement empirical CDF estimation. example, can implement HPJ bias-corrected empirical CDF estimation :  nekd(), hpjkd(), tojkd() functions enable implement kernel density estimation. example, can implement HPJ bias-corrected kernel density estimation :  function makes type figure using ggplot2 package. can customize via standard commands ggplot2 package. example, can customize title theme follows.  neecdf(), hpjecdf(), tojecdf(), nekd(), hpjkd(), tojkd() functions return mean_func(), acov_func(), acor_func() functions return estimated CDFs estimated density functions. Using functions, can make figures . example, can make figure HPJ bias-corrected density heterogeneous mean follows.
code: # install.packages("devtools") # if necessary # install.packages("ggplot2")  # if necessary devtools::install_github("tkhdyanagi/panelhetero", build_vignettes = TRUE) set.seed(1)  y <- panelhetero::simulation(N = 300, S = 50) set.seed(1)  result1 <- panelhetero::hpjmoment(data = y, acov_order = 0, acor_order = 1) result1$estimate #>         E(mean)         E(acov)         E(acor)       var(mean)       var(acov)  #>      0.02708997      0.36548190      0.29990482      0.92438720      0.03719496  #>       var(acor) cor(mean, acov) cor(mean, acor) cor(acov, acor)  #>      0.02660863      0.04421341     -0.08389775     -0.50469768 result1$se #>         E(mean)         E(acov)         E(acor)       var(mean)       var(acov)  #>     0.055583349     0.011792564     0.013009467     0.081889058     0.004113548  #>       var(acor) cor(mean, acov) cor(mean, acor) cor(acov, acor)  #>     0.003935298     0.065784897     0.067862036     0.058240864 result1$ci #>                 95% CI lower 95% CI upper #> E(mean)          -0.08318171   0.13752253 #> E(acov)           0.34217581   0.38783124 #> E(acor)           0.27323674   0.32419832 #> var(mean)         0.76989358   1.09443133 #> var(acov)         0.02904184   0.04549768 #> var(acor)         0.01923979   0.03463775 #> cor(mean, acov)  -0.08349429   0.17213130 #> cor(mean, acor)  -0.21216526   0.05112957 #> cor(acov, acor)  -0.61577864  -0.39102289 result2 <- panelhetero::hpjecdf(data = y,                                  acov_order = 0,                                  acor_order = 1,                                 R = 100,                                 ci = FALSE) result2$mean result3 <- panelhetero::hpjkd(data = y, acov_order = 0, acor_order = 1) result3$mean result3$mean +    ggplot2::ggtitle("") +    ggplot2::theme_classic() ggplot2::ggplot(data = data.frame(x = c(-3.5, 3.5)), ggplot2::aes(x = x)) +    ggplot2::stat_function(fun = result3$mean_func) +    ggplot2::ggtitle("")

title: Getting Started with the panelhetero Package
text: Ryo Okui, Takahide Yanagi (2019): “Panel data analysis heterogeneous dynamics”, Journal Econometrics, 212(2), 451-475. Ryo Okui, Takahide Yanagi (2020): “Kernel estimation panel data heterogeneous dynamics”, Econometrics Journal, 23(1), 156-175.

what: Panel Data Analysis with Heterogeneous Dynamics
title: Panel Data Analysis with Heterogeneous Dynamics
text: panelhetero package provides tools estimating degree heterogeneity acorss cross-sectional units using panel data. methods developed following papers: Okui Yanagi (2019) “Panel data analysis heterogeneous dynamics” Okui Yanagi (2020) “Kernel estimation panel data heterogeneous dynamics”.

title: Panel Data Analysis with Heterogeneous Dynamics
text: Run:
code: install.packages("panelhetero") # install.packages("devtools") # if necessary devtools::install_github("tkhdyanagi/panelhetero", build_vignettes = TRUE)

title: Panel Data Analysis with Heterogeneous Dynamics
text: details, see package vignette :

title: Panel Data Analysis with Heterogeneous Dynamics
text: Okui, R. Yanagi, T., 2019. Panel data analysis heterogeneous dynamics. Journal Econometrics, 212(2), pp.451-475. Link Okui, R. Yanagi, T., 2020. Kernel estimation panel data heterogeneous dynamics. Econometrics Journal, 23(1), pp.156-175. Link

what: The HPJ bias-corrected empirical CDF estimation — hpjecdf
title: The HPJ bias-corrected empirical CDF estimation — hpjecdf
text: `hpjecdf()` function enables implement HPJ bias-corrected estimation cumulative distribution function (CDF) heterogeneous mean, heterogeneous autocovariance, heterogeneous autocorrelation. method developed Okui Yanagi (2019). details, see package vignette `vignette("panelhetero")`.

title: The HPJ bias-corrected empirical CDF estimation — hpjecdf
code: hpjecdf(data, acov_order = 0, acor_order = 1, R = 1000, ci = TRUE)

title: The HPJ bias-corrected empirical CDF estimation — hpjecdf
text: data matrix panel data. row corresponds individual time series. acov_order non-negative integer order autocovariance. Default 0. acor_order positive integer order autocorrelation. Default 1. R positive integer number bootstrap repetitions. Default 1000. ci logical whether estimate confidence interval. Default TRUE.

title: The HPJ bias-corrected empirical CDF estimation — hpjecdf
text: list contains following elements. mean plot corresponding CDF acov plot corresponding CDF acor plot corresponding CDF mean_func function returns corresponding CDF acov_func function returns corresponding CDF acor_func function returns corresponding CDF mean_ci_func function returns 95 percent confidence interval corresponding CDF acov_ci_func function returns 95 percent confidence interval corresponding CDF acor_ci_func function returns 95 percent confidence interval corresponding CDF quantity matrix estimated heterogeneous quantities acov_order order autocovariance acor_order order autocorrelation N number cross-sectional units S length time series R number bootstrap repetitions
